item.title: Suicide Bomber in Kabul Strikes Packed Commuter Bus
item.description: At least seven people were killed and dozens were wounded in a rush-hour attack — the fourth major assault in the capital this year, officials said.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Danish Town Opens New Front in Immigration Culture War: Children’s Menus
item.description: Pork has become the latest weapon in a fight to preserve national identity after Randers, Denmark, voted to require day care centers and kindergartens to include it on menus.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Hong Kong’s Missing Booksellers
item.description: Why is Beijing using brute force to close down a tiny publisher of two-bit political gossip?
item.dc:creator: LIAN YI-ZHENG

item.title: ISIS Has Destroyed Iraq’s Oldest Christian Monastery
item.description: Satellite images show that St. Elijah’s Monastery, a 1,400-year-old stone sanctuary, was probably razed to rubble between August and September 2014.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Eros Hoagland for The New York Times
item.media:description: St. Elijah’s Monastery near Mosul, Iraq, in 2009. Satellite photos confirm the site was destroyed by Islamic State militants in 2014.

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader Condemns Mob Attack on Saudi Embassy
item.description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the assault that followed the execution of a Shiite cleric in Saudi Arabia was “detrimental to the country and Islam.”
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: A demonstration in Tehran this month after the execution of a prominent Shiite cleric in Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Sinosphere: Treatment of Foreigners in China a ‘Worrying Trend,’ E.U. Envoy Says
item.description: Hans Dietmar Schweisgut, speaking at a news conference on economic matters, addressed the recent string of expulsions and detentions of Europeans.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Ursula Gauthier, a French journalist, was expelled from China in December for an article she wrote on violence in the Xinjiang region.

item.title: Rivesaltes Journal: Memorial for France’s ‘Undesirables’ Echoes Debate Over Migrants
item.description: The ruins of an internment camp at Rivesaltes, where for decades waves of refugees and others persecuted in wars were once held, have been turned into a memorial.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of barracks at the Rivesaltes internment camp, north of Perpignan, France, now the site of a memorial.

item.title: Attack at Bacha Khan University in Pakistan Leaves at Least 22 Dead
item.description: The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the assault in northwestern Pakistan, which was among the most brazen in a long insurgency.
item.dc:creator: ISMAIL KHAN
item.media:description: Coffins holding the bodies of victims at a hospital after an attack at Bacha Khan University, in Charsadda, Pakistan, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Weighs Tighter Sanctions on North Korea if China Fails to Act
item.description: A day before a planned meeting with Chinese officials, a senior State Department envoy urged Beijing to do more to curb the North’s nuclear ambitions.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A Chinese paramilitary police officer standing guard outside the North Korean Embassy in Beijing.

item.title: Vietnam Objects to Chinese Oil Rig in Disputed Waters
item.description: While the dispute raised tensions between the neighbors, it did not approach levels seen in 2014, when anti-China demonstrations turned into deadly riots.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Luong Thai Linh
item.media:description: Nguyen Phu Trong, the Vietnam Communist Party’s secretary general, foreground; President Truong Tan Sang, right; and Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung, behind Mr. Trong; before the party congress in Hanoi on Wednesday.

item.title: Giving Voice to France’s Poorest Youth, With Rhymes and Beats
item.description: After the Paris terrorist attacks, hip-hop artists are clashing perhaps more than ever with the country’s expanding and vituperative far right.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The rapper Médine in his neighborhood in Le Havre, France.

item.title: Editorial: Mr. Obama’s Wise Call on a Prisoner Swap
item.description: The Iran case showed that the use of diplomacy was the best course.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: President Obama leaves the podium after speaking about the release of Americans by Iran.

item.title: Airdrops Called Too Risky a Way to Help Starving Syrians
item.description: American officials said that the Syrian government’s antiaircraft weapons posed a threat and that dropping aid to a populated area could hurt the very people it was meant to help.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN
item.media:description: Syrians waiting for the arrival of an aid convoy in the besieged town of Madaya last week.

item.title: Exodus Refugee Ship Flag Finds Safe Haven at Holocaust Museum
item.description: A flag from the Exodus, a ship carrying 4,500 Jewish refugees that was turned away from Palestine by the British in 1947, has been donated to the Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: ERIC LICHTBLAU
item.media:description: Sara J. Bloomfield of the Holocaust Memorial Museum with Bill Silverstein, right, and his brother, Tom, second from left.

item.title: Iran Negotiations Add to Special Envoy’s Reputation as ‘a Doer’
item.description: Brett H. McGurk, who served under President Bush and is now a special envoy for President Obama, worked tirelessly for 14 months to negotiate the exchange of prisoners with Iran.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Brett H. McGurk in Erbil, Iraq, in 2014 with Secretary of State John Kerry and Robert S. Beecroft, left, a former ambassador to Iraq. Mr. McGurk, who negotiated the hostage deal with Iran, is a special presidential envoy in the fight against the Islamic State.

item.title: World Briefing: Vietnam: Officials Warn China Over Oil Rig in Disputed Waters
item.description: The rig was at the center of a standoff between the countries in May 2014.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: Diplomacy and Sanctions, Yes. Left Unspoken on Iran? Sabotage.
item.description: An American covert sabotage program that began in the Clinton administration and steadily escalated over the next 15 years also played a critical role in persuading the Iranians.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: On Sunday, President Obama announced that Iran had freed five Iranian-American nationals, and that the United States and European nations had lifted oil and financial sanctions on Iran.

item.title: C.D.C. Urges Zika Testing for Some Who Are Pregnant
item.description: The guidelines, though seen as imperfect, offer a way to proceed with worried patients who have recently lived in or traveled to an area where the mosquito-borne virus is being transmitted.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: A researcher at São Paulo University in Brazil holds a container of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, which can spread the Zika virus. On Tuesday, the C.D.C. issued guidelines for pregnant women who have visited countries where the virus is spreading.

item.title: ISIS Magazine Confirms ‘Jihadi John’ Death
item.description: The most recent issue of the militant group’s online publication, Dabiq, included a eulogy for Mohammed Emwazi, a British citizen.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ASHLEY SOUTHALL

item.title: 9 Are Arrested as Israeli Police Investigate Holocaust Trip Price-Fixing
item.description: The arrests were made in connection with a suspected price-fixing scheme for high school trips to former Nazi camps in Poland, the Israeli police said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
